An enclosed boat with the competitor sitting on a fixed seat for one person using a double bladed paddle
An enclosed boat with the competitor sitting on a fixed seat for two people using double bladed paddles
An enclosed boat with the competitor sitting on a fixed seat for four people using double bladed paddles
A martial art where chops, punches, kicks and throws are used to defeat an opponent.
Japanese traditional martial art using a bamboo sword, sometimes called Japanese fencing.
Japanese traditional martial art using a bamboo bow and arrows, sometimes called Japanese archery.
Two teams of helmeted and padded players try and outscore each other using a netted stick and hard ball.

Luge (French word for sled) is competed in singles or doubles. The competitor(s) lay on their back on an open sled and race down a course. The competitor(s) and the sled must be in contact when passing the finishing line. The competitor can steer the sled
A road race where competitors run 42.195km, generally through city streets
The Modern Pentathlon comprises five events run over a single day in the following order: shooting, fencing, swimming, horse riding and running.
Racing with boats with engines
Racing with cars
Races for one or more drivers over a long and set distance or time
Using less powerful motors than the Formula One, designated construction teams race over varied circuits the world over in speed races for individual and team honours over a season.
Single cockpit car racing where 20 or so competitors race head to head over varied circuits around the world to win Grand Prix points in an individual and constructors championship
North American top range professional league speed racing over circuits.
Stage races over dirt tracks
A season of endurance races over closed circuits including dirt tracks, roads and even snowy conditions featuring specials using adapted road cars with a driver and co-pilot.
Races with 2, 3 or 4 wheels vehicles with a saddle and handlebars
A road race of consistency and endurance
A race of speed, endurance and regularity over varied surfaces such as through forests and on dirt tracks
A race competed on turf
Team sport where drivers play a ball
Raced over dirt tracks featuring severe mounds
Capacity class 1000ccm
Races run over regular roads
Of different engine sizes but attached to a side car featuring a passenger
Race involving up to six riders competing over a flat oval track. Speedway motorcycles use only one gear and have no brakes
A race of consistency and endurance over varied terrain
Japanese traditional martial art using a pole sword made of wood. 'Naginata' means a spear with a curved blade.
A woman's sport similar to basketball though without a board behind the basket
An individual time-trial over a route marked out by beacons. The competitor has to search out and find in a specific order. The contestant makes his way with the help of a compass and map
An individual ski time-trial over a route marked out by beacons, that the competitor has to search out and find in a specific order. The contestant makes his way with the help of a compass and map
Jumping from an aeroplane using a parachute, competitions are precision landings, voltige, individual and team

With the aid of a mallet two teams of four horsemen try and knock a bamboo ball into the opponents goal over a pitch 250m long and 150m wide. The game is divided into 4, 6, or 8 time periods of 7min 30sec called chukkas.
A cue sport on a table with pockets, played with different numbers of balls
Races between motor boats on rivers or lakes
A discipline where wild horses or bulls must be mounted and mastered
Rodeo discipline
Rodeo discipline
Rodeo discipline
Rodeo discipline
Rodeo discipline
Rodeo discipline
Rodeo discipline
Team sport similar to ice hockey, executed on 4 wheel roller skates with sticks and a ball
Boat racing usually on flat calm waters with boats for 1, 2, 4 or 8 rowers
Four person boats with just one oar each and with a team mate to give directions
Two person boats with just one oar each and with a team mate to give directions
Four person boats with just one oar each and without a team mate to give directions
Two person boats with just one oar each and without a team mate to give directions
Two person boats with two oars each
Eight person boats with just one oar each and with a team mate to give directions
Four person boats with two oars each and without a team mate to give directions
Single person boats with two oars

A type of rugby where two teams of 13 compete on a pitch by running with and passing an oval ball. Points are scored by touching down the ball behind the goal line or kicking it between goal posts. Governed by Rugby League International Federation.

A type of rugby where two teams of 15 compete on a pitch by running with and passing an oval ball. Points are scored by touching down the ball behind the goal line or kicking it between goal posts. Governed by the World Rugby organization.

A type of rugby union where two teams of 7 compete on a pitch by running with and passing an oval ball. Points are scored by touching down the ball behind the goal line or kicking it between goal posts. Governed by the World Rugby organization.
Sailing boat racing over a route
Sailing boats with multiple hulls
Single hulled vessel without a fixed keel
Single hulled vessel with a fixed keel
Sailing event
Sailing vessels across oceans as part of a competitive race.
Sailing vessels around the world as a race
Sailing oceans as an individual, as part of a race.
Races either clockwise or anti clockwise around the globe without stopping at any ports between start and finish of race.
The game like volleyball which must not use a hand. The ball made of rattan is used.
A ball game involving 2 teams with curved sticks called camans. The object is to score goals by hitting the small leather ball through the goals.
Precision sport using a hand gun, rifle or shotgun
Shooting event using a pistol
Shooting event using a rifle
Shooting event with an airgun and a target that moves sideways
Shooting event using a shotgun
Shooting event which involves shooting at special flying targets, known as clay pigeons or clay targets

In skeleton the competitor lay on his/hers stomach when racing down the course. The competitor must be on the sled when crossing the finishing line. The total time of all races in a competition is added together. Skeleton is considered the first sliding s
A winter sport using different types of skis
Racing downhill on snow-covered slopes using alpine techniques and equipment. The slopes contain intermediate gates which are spaced according to the discipline involved.
Competitors perform a series of breathtaking acrobatic leaps from a prepared jump. Combined with moguls, jumps and ski ballet.
Alpine skiing on roller skis and grass
Practiced in relatively-flat, snowy countryside and based on power and endurance.
Competitors descend a snow covered elevated ramp on skis and try to fly off it as far as possible, receiving marks for distance, style of flight and landing
Parachuting competitions with long distance falls without using a parachute
A cue sport with balls on a table to be potted in a specific order
Practiced with a single board (rather than two skis)

A form of football played by two teams of 11 competing on a pitch by kicking a spherical ball. Points are scored by kicking or heading the ball into a goal. Governed by the Fdration Internationale de Football Association.
Similar to baseball but with a larger and softer ball, a thinner bat, shorter gaps between bases and less innings
Timed races competed by two skaters at a time on an oval ice track
A racquet sport of strategy and endurance played by singles or doubles teams in a walled court with a small rubber ball
A combat sport of speed and rapidity with much ceremony where two contestants try to throw or slap a competitor out of a marked area. Generally practiced in Japan by large men.
Water sport where contestants catch and ride waves upright on a surfboard
A water sport where contestants swim as fast as possible in a given style and win races by being the first to touch home
Swimming style, on the back, legs move in flapping motion whilst arms propel the swimmer forward
Swimming style , on the front, effecting forward and outward push movements with the arms and backward and outward pushes with the legs

Swimming style , swum on the front with the shoulders remaining parallel to the water both arms moving in simultaneous windmill fashion, the legs remain together and are moved in a flapping motion. The most physical of all styles.
Any swimming style may be employed, though front crawl is universally employed
A combination of four different swimming styles in one race.
A long distance open water swimming
Team of swimmers swim a relay in the swimming style of their choice
Team relay race involving a combination of four different swimming styles
Races competed in a 25m length pool
In the free programme, music, movements and their order of execution are not restricted.

Contestants obtain points from 10 sitting judges by executing certain synchronised artistic shapes and movements in the water. In the technical programme, competitors must execute a range of specific moves in a given order.
A racquet sport for two or four (in doubles), who compete at a table divided by a net using a small bat to play a lightweight ball
A martial art of Korean origin

A sport where two players, four in doubles, equipped with a racket compete by hitting the ball over a net into the opponent's side of the court with the aim of putting it out of reach within the regulation lines, thus winning points.
A game in which a player scores points by trying to knock down ten 'pins' using a ball - if unsuccessful the player has a second attempt. A game consists of ten frames.
An endurance multi-sport where competitors first swim, then cycle and then run a road race. Distances vary according to the competition.
Two teams pulling against each other on a rope
Two teams of six record points by hitting a ball over a net into the opponent's half of the court, keeping it in the air at all times. Points are won when opponents fail to return the ball.

Two teams of two players compete on a sand court. Unlike indoor volleyball, points are scored only when the serving team wins a rally or forces an error. The sand surface makes it more physically demanding than volleyball
Played in a pool between two teams of 7, who must stay afloat and can only use one hand to pass the ball or swim with it before trying to throw it into the opponents net to score goals.
On one or two skis contestants are pulled by a power boat along the water's surface
A strength test where competitors lift as heavy a weight as possible
The bar is first lifted to the shoulders and then jerk it above the head and keep it there while maintaining straight legs
A strength test where competitors lift as heavy a weight as possible
The bar must be lifted from floor to above the head in one movement
Contestants must complete a marked out course as fast as possible on a windsurf board
Combat sport where each wrestler attempts to win over his adversary, by holding both shoulders on the ground (fall) long enough to be in control. Points can also be decisive.
A style where leg holds are allowed
A style where the only holds allowed are those between the head and the belt
Traditional Swiss sport similar to wrestling with specific rules
Chinese traditional martial art.
Actions, including fines and suspensions levied by sports organisations and teams
Using drugs to enable competitiveness in sports
Using drugs to improve competitiveness in sports
Means and ways to check the use of drugs in sports
Use of drugs for medical reasons as permitted by sport regulators
An event featuring one or more sport competitions
A competition where individuals or teams from countries from one continent may participate. Called a "Championship".
A competition where individuals or teams from countries from one continent may participate. Called a "Cup".
A competition where individuals or teams from countries from one continent may participate. Called "Games".
A competition where individuals or teams from different countries may participate. Called a "Championship".
A competition where individuals or teams from different countries may participate. Called a "Cup".
A competition where individuals or teams from different countries may participate. Called "Games".
A competition where individuals or teams from one country may participate. Called a "Championship".
A competition where individuals or teams from one country may participate. Called a "Cup".
A competition where individuals or teams from one country may participate. Called "Games".
A competition where individuals or teams from a region of a country may participate. Called a "Championship".
A competition where individuals or teams from a region of a country may participate. Called a "Cup".
A competition where individuals or teams from a region of a country may participate. Called "Games".
A competition where individuals or teams from the five continents may participate. Called "World Championship".
A competition where individuals or teams from the five continents may participate. Called "World Cup".
A competition where individuals or teams from the five continents may participate. Called "World Games".
Commercial issues related to sport
Organisations or associations of sports
Commercial facility for sporting event
Prediction of the course of the weather in the future either near term or long term
Special weather conditions
Numerical facts about the weather such as temperature, barometric pressure, river levels, humidity, high and low tides and the like
Alerts to the general populace about severe weather coming their way
Government policies affecting cultural affairs
Variation of the musical theater with Anglo-Saxon origins
Variation of the musical theater with Central European origins
Temporary presentation of art in museums, art halls or galleries
Market place to display and trade goods or services
An analyst's recommendation for particular stocks. May include the analysts price target for the stock.
An analyst's recommendation to buy particular stocks. May include the analysts price target for the stock.
An analyst's recommendation to hold particular stocks. May include the analysts price target for the stock.
An analyst's recommendation to sell particular stocks. May include the analysts price target for the stock.
Remarkable price movements of a particular stock.
Sportive activities in the mountains including climbing and hiking
Social event with dancing
Unpaid service for the community as civilian
Mandatory service with the national military for a limited period of time
Improving the co-existence of groups of the society
Government policies affecting sports
Change of a member of one team to another team
Nordic ski race competed in relatively-flat, snowy countryside on narrow skis.
Competition combining cross-country skiing and ski jumping
Races competed by four or more skaters at a time on a small oval ice track
Gymnasts perform artistic and acrobatic moves on different apparatus. There are 6 events for men and 4 for women.
Races combining downhill and cross-country skiing events with unique Telemark techniques and equipment.
Competition between two players using a chequered board with 16 pieces to each side, each with specific ranges of movement depending on their identity.
Various competitions using wheeled equipment such as roller skates, inline skates, and skateboards.
Competitions involving stunts and acrobatic feats performed on a skateboard using various ramps and other obstacles.

Martial arts are codified systems and traditions of combat practices, which are practiced for a variety of reasons: self-defense, competition, physical health and fitness, entertainment, as well as mental, physical, and spiritual development.
The process of designing, launching and running a new business.
Written contracts between companies and public authorities for the execution of works, the supply of products or the provision of services.
Products or services provided with simple skills and tools, as opposed to by mass industrial production.
A network of devices using microchips, electronic sensors and communication by the Internet
Management of assets or funds to increase income by investing in stocks, bonds, mutual funds, hedge funds etc.
Creating and maintaining a relationship with the customers to increase sales.
Services for executing payments including cash, cheque, credit card, debit card, direct debit, electronic funds transfer, internet banking, electronic and mobile payment.
Durable goods used in the production of other goods or services.
Rolling stock manufacturers, suppliers, railways and signals industry, maintenance and repair.
Manufacture of medical and surgical devices for diagnosis and treatment such as optical and imaging equipment.
Hygiene products, care and nutrition for pets.
An electronic cigarette is a battery-operated device with an atomizer and a cartridge containing either a nicotine or a non-nicotine liquid solution.
Supply chain, inventory management and transportation of products.
Peer-to-peer-based sharing of access to goods and services.
A small and medium enterprise (SME) is a company whose number of employees, balance, and turnover cannot exceed certain limits set by the country where it is located.
Authority responsible for the regulation or supervision of a business sector.
Public or private actions carried out to develop a region.

A sport in which swimmers, in solo, duet or team configurations, perform coordinated or identical movements in time to music. They are judged and are awarded points for body position, control, and the degree of difficulty of the moves.

A form of football developed in Rugby (England) played with an oval ball that may be kicked, carried and passed from hand to hand. Points are scored when one team carries the ball over the other team's goal line or kicks the ball between two goal posts.
